expanded_description: This section introduces Newton's First Law of Motion, often called the law of inertia. It states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced (net) force. This law defines the concept of inertia and establishes the condition for equilibrium.

core_concept.principle: Newton's First Law: An object at rest remains at rest, and an object in motion continues in motion with constant velocity (constant speed in a straight line) unless acted upon by a net external force.
core_concept.explanation: This law introduces the idea of inertia: the natural tendency of objects to resist changes in their state of motion. It also defines an inertial reference frame – one in which the law holds. A key consequence is that when the net force on an object is zero, its acceleration is zero, meaning it is either at rest or moving with constant velocity.

image.alt: Illustration of a stationary object and a moving object in space, with no forces acting, showing they remain in their state of motion
image.caption: Newton's First Law: Without a net force, an object's velocity does not change.

sections.introduction: Galileo first conceived the idea that objects resist changes in motion, which Newton formalized as his first law. Understanding this law is crucial for recognizing when forces are balanced and when they are not.

key_concept.definition: Newton's First Law states that an object will maintain its state of motion (rest or constant velocity) unless compelled to change by a net external force.
key_concept.context: This law explains why we feel thrown forward when a car stops suddenly – our bodies tend to keep moving forward. It also tells us that if an object is moving at constant velocity, the forces on it must be balanced (net force = 0).

principles.statement: Inertia is the property of an object to resist changes in its velocity. The greater the mass, the greater the inertia.
principles.application: A more massive object is harder to start moving or stop than a less massive one, even in the absence of friction.
principles.example: Pushing a car to get it moving is much harder than pushing a bicycle, because the car has more inertia (mass).
principles.analogy: Like a heavy piece of furniture – it takes a lot of effort to get it moving, and once moving, it's hard to stop quickly.

principles.principle: Net Force Zero Implies Constant Velocity
principles.statement: If the vector sum of all forces acting on an object is zero ($\sum \vec{F} = 0$), then the object will either remain at rest or continue moving with constant velocity.
principles.application: This is the condition for mechanical equilibrium. It applies to objects at rest (static equilibrium) and objects moving uniformly (dynamic equilibrium).
principles.example: A book resting on a table has gravity down and normal force up, summing to zero; thus it remains at rest. A skydiver falling at terminal velocity has weight down and air resistance up, net force zero, so constant velocity.

principles.statement: Newton's first law holds only in inertial reference frames – frames that are not accelerating. In such frames, an object with no net force has zero acceleration.
principles.application: For most everyday situations, the ground is a good approximation of an inertial frame. A car accelerating is non‑inertial; inside it, objects appear to have forces (like being pushed back in the seat) even though no physical force is acting.
principles.example: In a smoothly moving train at constant velocity, a ball dropped falls straight down (inertial frame). If the train accelerates, the ball appears to curve backward (non‑inertial effects).

characteristics: Object moving at constant velocity (dynamic equilibrium)
All forces balance in every direction
classifications.behavior: When in equilibrium, an object's velocity is constant. This can be verified by drawing a free body diagram and checking that the sum of forces in each direction is zero.

examples.explanation: A sign hanging from wires: tension forces upward balance weight downward; net force zero → sign remains at rest.
Engine force forward equals air resistance and friction backward; net force zero → constant velocity.

classifications.behavior: When net force is not zero, the object's velocity changes. This leads into Newton's second law.

examples.explanation: Foot applies a net force, ball accelerates from rest.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Equilibrium
worked_examples.problem: A crate is being pushed across a rough floor at constant speed. Is the crate in equilibrium? Explain.

step_by_step.explanation: Equilibrium means net force = 0, which implies constant velocity (including zero).
The crate moves at constant speed in a straight line, so its velocity is constant.
Forces: weight down, normal force up (balanced). Push forward, friction backward (balanced because speed constant).
Since velocity is constant, net force must be zero. Therefore the crate is in dynamic equilibrium.

worked_examples.final_answer: Yes, the crate is in dynamic equilibrium because it moves with constant velocity, implying zero net force.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Constant velocity → net force = 0 → equilibrium (even if moving).

worked_examples.title: Applying Newton's First Law
worked_examples.problem: An astronaut in deep space, far from any stars or planets, throws a wrench. Describe the motion of the wrench after it leaves the astronaut's hand, according to Newton's first law.

step_by_step.explanation: In deep space, negligible gravity and no other interactions. Net force is essentially zero.
With no net force, the wrench will maintain its velocity at the instant it leaves the hand.
The wrench will continue moving in a straight line at constant speed forever (unless it encounters something).

worked_examples.final_answer: The wrench will move with constant velocity (constant speed in a straight line) indefinitely.
worked_examples.concept_applied: In the absence of net force, an object in motion stays in motion with constant velocity.

image.alt: Diagram showing a person in a car lurching forward when the car stops suddenly
image.caption: Inertia explains why passengers lurch forward when a car stops – their bodies tend to keep moving.

sections.introduction: Many intuitive ideas about motion contradict Newton's first law. Recognizing these misconceptions helps in correctly applying the law.

classifications.value: Believing that moving objects require a continuous force to keep moving
characteristics: Thinking that if you stop pushing, an object naturally stops
Confusing the need to overcome friction with a general principle
classifications.behavior: In reality, objects stop because of unbalanced forces like friction. In the absence of any force (e.g., in space), they continue moving forever.

examples.explanation: A ball rolling on grass eventually stops because its 'force of motion' runs out.
The ball stops because friction (an unbalanced force) acts opposite to motion. In the absence of friction, it would keep rolling.

classifications.value: Assuming that if an object is at rest, there are no forces acting on it
characteristics: Forgetting that balanced forces can also produce rest
Thinking only moving objects have forces
classifications.behavior: An object at rest can have several forces acting on it, as long as they sum to zero. Gravity always acts, so rest implies at least one other force balances it.

examples.explanation: A book on a table has no forces because it's not moving.
The book has weight down and normal force up, balancing each other.

classifications.value: Assuming that an object moving with constant velocity still has a net force in the direction of motion
characteristics: Thinking a car on cruise control must have a forward net force
Forgetting that other forces (like friction) can balance the driving force
classifications.behavior: Constant velocity means zero acceleration, so net force is zero. The driving force is exactly balanced by resistive forces.

examples.explanation: A skydiver at terminal velocity must have a net downward force because they are still moving down.
At terminal velocity, weight equals air resistance, so net force is zero; constant velocity results.

image.caption: Common misconceptions about motion contradict Newton's first law.

summary: Newton's First Law, the law of inertia, states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force. This law defines inertia as the resistance to changes in motion; mass is a measure of inertia. When the net force on an object is zero, it is in equilibrium – either static (at rest) or dynamic (constant velocity). Equilibrium requires that all forces balance in every direction, as can be seen in free body diagrams. The law holds only in inertial reference frames (non‑accelerating frames). Common misconceptions include believing that a continuous force is needed to sustain motion (friction is usually the cause of slowing), that stationary objects have no forces (they have balanced forces), and that constant velocity implies a net force (it implies zero net force). Newton's first law lays the groundwork for understanding the relationship between forces and motion, which is quantified in the second law.
